extendedInfo.description: Egyptian myths were metaphorical stories intended to illustrate and explain the gods' actions and roles in nature. The details of the events they recounted could change as long as they conveyed the same symbolic meaning, so many myths exist in different and conflicting versions. Mythical narratives were rarely written in full, and more often texts only contain episodes from or allusions to a larger myth. Knowledge of Egyptian mythology, therefore, is derived mostly from hymns that detail the roles of specific deities, from ritual and magical texts which describe actions related to mythic events, and from funerary texts which mention the roles of many deities in the afterlife. Some information is also provided by allusions in secular texts. Finally, Greeks and Romans such as Plutarch recorded some of the extant myths late in Egyptian history.Â· CHAPTER I. Father Gods and Mother GoddessesÂ· CHAPTER XV. The Rise of AmonÂ· CHAPTER XVI. Tale of the Fugitive PrinceÂ· CHAPTER XVII. Egypt's Golden AgeÂ· CHAPTER XVIII. Myths and Lays of the Middle KingdomÂ· CHAPTER XIX. The Island of EnchantmentÂ· CHAPTER XX. The Hyksos and their Strange GodÂ· CHAPTER XXI. Joseph and the ExodusÂ· CHAPTER XXII. The Religious Revolt of the Poet KingÂ· CHAPTER XXVII. The Empire of Rameses and the Homeric AgeÂ· CHAPTER XXVIII. Egypt and the Hebrew MonarchyÂ· CHAPTER XXIX. reviews.title: Um, Grammer?
reviews.comment: Good app with good info, but it\'d be better if it all wasn\'t run-on sentences. They make it hard to understand. Use proper pronunciation, if this is a classy or nice app.

reviews.title: Difficult to follow
reviews.comment: I love ancient Egypt and figured this would be a great app...it\'s very difficult to read however. If the grammar was correct it\'d be ok, but I can barely follow the sentences.
reviews.author: A Google User
